page.title: 16NATURE RESERVE ON ARNE
page.content: Then the trail passes through dry heathland which is colonised by Scots Pine and Silver Birch,which grows rapidly and is the first tree to invade heathland.Several oak and rowan trees which are secondary colonisers, can be seen, and if left to develop naturally the habitat would eventually become deciduous woodland.Some silver birches host razor-sharp fungus,a parasitic brachet fungus.Holly,yew and ivy grow here. The trail comes down to the marshy ground at the edge of the harbour.Here the mudflats are colonised by spartina-a halophyte.Also fresh water marsh is seen containing many typical fresh water plants;parsley,water dropwort,wild celery,marsh pennywort, marsh bedstraw,greater bird's foot trefoil, gypsywort and corn sow-thistle.
